Tel.: +55 11 3091 5647; fax: +55 11 3091 5718. Abstract The use of quantum information has been proposed as an approach to deal with biological data (Piqueira, J.R.C., Serboncini, F.A., Monteiro, L.H.A., 2006. Biological models: measuring variability with classical and quantum information. J. Theor. Biol. 242 (2), 309–313). Using three-trophic level systems as examples, we show how to model population data by expressing the system states with q-bits. The system time evolution is given by the state transition matrices which relate the states to successive time intervals. It is a complementary way of looking at the problem which is usually modeled with deterministic differential equations. This is possible because the dynamics of interacting populations in three-trophic level systems is a problem with several coupled variables and, consequently, complex dynamical behaviors seem to result. The non deterministic dynamics generated by the state transition matrices is supposed to model the biological system as a whole, with real data expressing even the global effects of small disturbances in the ecological parameters. Keywords Herbivores Information Population Predator q-Bits Three-trophic system 1 Introduction A discussion with long tradition in ecology is one of population dynamics in three-trophic systems, i.e., systems composed of plant, herbivores and predator (Hunter and Price, 1992; Halaj and Wise, 2001). Modeling population problems with the use of deterministic ordinary differential equations is an approach inspired by Classical Mechanics and successfully applied to Biology (Murray, 2002). For trophic structures in ecosystem models, there have been several well conducted studies in such a way (Pahl-Wostl, 1997; Sazykina et al., 2000). This work meant to be an alternative methodological idea to deal with biological data considering the Quantum Mechanics formalism, while it describes a system under study as a whole. Population data are converted in probabilities and the state of the system in each time interval can be expressed by a linear combination of orthogonal states | 0 〉 and | 1 〉 . The time evolution between two successive states is expressed by state transition matrices, which capture the variability of the system, including effects of small disturbances on parameters that appear as fluctuations in the state transition matrices (Piqueira et al., 2006). In order to elucidate the procedures, we have used data collected from two systems that, in a simplified version composed of plants, their main herbivores and the main predators found in the plants, are supposed to be three-trophic. They occur in a tropical ecosystem, a mesophytic semi-deciduous forest at Japi Mountain, in São Paulo State, South-East Brazil. This ecosystem has a well-defined climatic variability: there is a wet and hot season from November to March, and a dry and cold season from April to September, with a transition season between September and October. The former system consists of plant Desmodium discolor Vog. (Fabaceae: Papilionoideae), herbivores Urbanus spp. (Lepidoptera: Hesperiidae), and predator Runcinioides argenteus (Araneae: Thomisidae). The latter is composed of plant Desmodium uncinatum (Jacg.) DC. (Fabaceae: Papilionoideae) and the same herbivores and predator of the former one. Actually, the diet of spider R. argenteus is not restricted to herbivores Urbanus spp. but, as it is the main predator in the system considered here, its abundance plays a relevant role in the larvae dynamics,which allows us to consider the plant–larvae–spider as a tri-trophic system. A common feature of both plants, D. discolor and D. uncinatum, is the presence of hooked trichomes: in D. discolor, these trichomes are located in the leaves, while in D. uncinatum they are concentrated in the stems. These hooked trichomes act as a mechanical defense against herbivores since trichomes make it difficult for herbivores to move through the plant or even trap some of them, and this effect is stronger in D. uncinatum. Herbivores caught by trichomes die of starvation or are eaten by predators that can walk along the plant without being caught by trichomes. By using concepts from Quantum Information Theory (Bennett and Di Vincenzo, 2000; Hirvensalo, 2001; Piqueira, 2004; Piqueira et al., 2006) we have expressed the data as states of the systems in q-bit notation, i.e., linear combinations of orthogonal states | 0 〉 and | 1 〉 . Adjusting the data with evolution algorithms, we have estimated the transition state matrices that express the dynamical behavior of plants, herbivores and spiders for each given system. When we examine the theoretical evolution of the systems described by the calculated transition matrices and compare the results with the measured data, we conclude that the use of dynamics in a Quantum Mechanics way is a good strategy to model this type of ecological systems. Furthermore, the calculated state transition matrices could be used to evaluate the linear part of the vector field representing the Dynamical System (Guckenheimer and Holmes, 1983) if deterministic differential equations approach is chosen. 2 Methods The study of the two tri-trophic systems was carried out for 20 months (from May, 2000 to December, 2001). Monthly, around 50 plants of each system were analyzed; and the amount of mature leaves, as well as the populations of eggs and herbivores larvae Urbanus spp., and predators Runcinioides argenteus were measured. The plants were examined once a month, for 20 and 13 months, for D. discolor and D. uncinatum, respectively. We counted the number of plants with herbivores (eggs and larvae), the amount of plants with predators (spiders), the total number of leaves and the total number of mature leaves. Table 1 shows the data for D. discolor and Table 2 those for D. uncinatum. Usually, information is obtained with the use of binary digits (bits); and a state of each plant in stage i could be represented by strings of zeros (0) and ones (1) (Reza, 1961), with each position indicating, for instance, the presence of herbivores (eggs and larvae) and predators (spiders). This is an individual approach for modeling the system and, therefore, an individual string should be associated to each leaf. In order to present a description for the whole set of leaves, we have used the Quantum Information idea of each state of the whole system being described by a linear combination of orthogonal q-bits | 0 〉 and | 1 〉 (Bennett and Di Vincenzo, 2000; Hirvensalo, 2001; Piqueira, 2004). For either set of plants, D. discolor and D. uncinatum, we have represented the state in stage i as four linear combinations of q-bits, α e , i , α l , i , α s , i , which correspond to the presence of eggs, larvae and spiders in the plants, and α m , i , relating to the presence of mature leaves among the whole set of leaves. Each α x , i is expressed by (Bennett and Di Vincenzo, 2000; Hirvensalo, 2001; Piqueira, 2004; Piqueira et al., 2006): (1) α x , i = α x , i 0 | 0 〉 + α x , i 1 | 1 〉 , with x representing e (eggs), l (larvae), s (spiders) and m (mature leaves). In Eq. (1), α e , i 0 , α l , i 0 and α s , i 0 represent the square-root of the probability of a plant having eggs, larvae and spiders, in stage i, respectively. In the same equation, α m , i 0 represents the square-root of the probability of a leave being mature, in stage i. α e , i 1 , α l , i 1 and α s , i 1 represent the square-root of the probability of a plant not having eggs, larvae and spiders, in stage i, respectively. α m , i 1 represents the probability of a leave not being mature, in stage i. Consequently, (2) ( α x , i 0 ) 2 + ( α x , i 1 ) 2 = 1 . For our purpose, probabilities are supposed to be equal to the relative frequencies presented by the collected data. From this formulation, we could express how states change as time develops, by using state transition matrices ( A x ) as follows: (3) α x , i + 1 0 α x , i + 1 1 = a 11 x a 12 x a 21 x a 22 x α x , i 0 α x , i 1 . To obtain the state transition matrices with a minimum square error fitting, we used an evolutionary algorithm. We started with a random generated set of solutions – in this case, a set of transition matrices – and applied to it operations of selection, mutation and re-combination for a certain number of periods. The selection operation applied to the initial random set of solutions neglects the worst ones corresponding to higher errors in the estimated dynamic. Then, mutation operations, i.e., slight random modifications are applied to the low-error solutions resulting from the selection stage. Re-combination generates a new set of solutions and the process re-starts controlled by a stop criterion. As a consequence, at the end of the process, we obtained a better suited set, that is, a set of matrices for which the mean square error is minimum. For this fitting procedure, we used a canonical form of evolution strategy with 20 individuals in the set and the corresponding offspring of 60 individuals, for each generation. The implementation goes on with discrete re-combination for objective variables and intermediate re-combination for the strategic parameters (Back et al., 1997a, b; Michalewics, 1999). The mean square errors ( δ x ) are calculated by: (4) δ x = ∑ i = 1 n ( α x , i 0 − α ¯ x , i 0 ) 2 + ( α x , i 1 − α ¯ x , i 1 ) 2 N , where bars indicate the estimated values given by the state transition matrices and N is the total number of months considered in each case. Using this fitting criterion, we calculated eight state transition matrices, four for D. discolor ( ( A e d ) , ( A l d ) , ( A s d ) and ( A m d ) ) and four for D. uncinatum ( ( A e u ) , ( A l u ) , ( A s u ) and ( A m u ) ). Thus, theoretical dynamics was achieved and comparisons with real data could be performed. The obtained matrices are local estimations (Ljung, 1999) of how populations depend on the instant of time. Consequently, these matrices can be identified with the linear part of the Taylors expansion of the vector field (Guckenheimer and Holmes, 1983) representing the dynamic of the population system, when a deterministic differential equation approach is used to model the process. 3 Results The results were divided into two groups according to the system considered and referred to by the name of the plant: D. discolor and D. uncinatum. 3.1 D. discolor The described fitting process generated the state transition matrices given by: A e d = 0.6770 0.0373 − 0.1010 1.0543 , A l d = 0.4632 0.0579 0.1010 0.9910 , A s d = 0.4567 0.0976 0.0863 0.9851 , A m d = 0.8861 0.1310 0.1130 0.8747 . Mean square errors are given in Table 3 . Figs. 1–4 show the behavior throughout time for α e 0 , α l 0 , α s 0 and α m 0 , respectively. The population of mature leaves in D. discolor have a clear association with climatic variability, as shown in Fig. 4. As the dry-cold season develops, water availability in the environment decreases and the plant D. discolor starts losing its leaves, which is an adaptive strategy to reduce water waste. This process causes a significant fall in α m 0 and the low value goes on until the beginning of the wet-hot season. From then on, α m 0 increases to a constant value up to the beginning of a new dry season. Then, α m 0 decreases and the cycle starts all over again. General tendencies of increasing or decreasing in mature leaves ( α m 0 ) are followed, respectively, by increase or decrease in eggs and larvae of Urbanus spp. ( α e 0 , α l 0 ). However, as Figs. 1 and 2 show, this response by herbivores may be 1 or 2 months delayed because the availability of resources, i.e., the mature leaves population, may vary. Thus, the eggs and larvae of Urbanus spp. in D. discolor have similar patterns of behavior: α e 0 , α l 0 are high between the end of the wet season and the beginning of the dry season, whereas their amount falls dramatically from the middle of the dry season to the beginning of the rainy season. The predator response ( α s 0 ) to variations in climate and in D. discolor seems to be more immediate, as shown in Fig. 3. Low values of ( α s 0 ) for R. argenteus coincide with the dry-cold season, and high ones with the wet-hot season. As R. argenteus is a general predator, its dynamics might indirectly indicate an adjustment between the predator population ( α s 0 ) and the availability of preys ( α e 0 , α l 0 ). Figs. 1–3 show that, for D. discolor, the increase in the spiders’ population implies a strong decrease in eggs and larvae up to a maximum amount of spiders in the 10th month. From then on, spiders tend to have a constant value while eggs and larvae assume an oscillating character. 3.2 D. uncinatum The described fitting process generated the state transition matrices given by: A e u = 0.5817 0.0861 0.1142 0.9740 , A l u = 0.5210 0.0747 0.0930 0.9834 , A s u = 0.6522 0.0392 0.0759 0.9967 , A m u = A = 0.7789 0.2737 0.2321 0.7158 . Mean square errors are given in Table 4 . Figs. 5– 8 show the behavior throughout time for α e 0 , α l 0 , α s 0 and α m 0 , respectively. For mature leaves of D. uncinatum, the values of α m 0 are highest in the rainy season and in early dry season, while they decrease as the dry season develops, as shown in Fig. 8. As in D. discolor the loss of leaves in D. uncinatum is an adaptive strategy to reduce water waste in adverse season. Climatic variations also affect Urbanus spp. eggs in D. uncinatum, as shown in Fig. 5, with α e 0 being higher in late wet season and early dry season. As an adverse season develops; a dramatic fall occurs and goes on up to the beginning of a new rainy season. Similar behavior is found in α s 0 , related to spiders R. argenteus present in D. uncinatum according to Fig. 7. In the first months, high α s 0 corresponds to low α l 0 , and vice versa, shown in Fig. 6. A slightly different behavior sets in as time goes by, stabilizing spiders population while the eggs and larvae take on oscillation patterns around low values for α s 0 , α e 0 and α l 0 . 4 Conclusions Examining the mean square error for the several cases, with a typical value of 0.01, we can conclude that the use of q-bits and state transition matrices to express the population of three-trophic systems might be a useful way to model the whole dynamics of ecological systems. Also, fitting evolution algorithm seems to be adequate to adjust theoretical dynamics to biological data, and further observation points might provide a better fitted set of state transition matrices. Based on the tendencies shown in the graphics of α e 0 , α l 0 , α s 0 and α m 0 , we have explored the dynamical behavior of populations of the tree-trophic systems proposed as examples here and several useful conclusions were obtained. As the mathematical process described is simple analytically and easy to implement by using well known computational methods, it can be viewed as a complementary alternative to model ecological systems. Furthermore, to combine this approach with deterministic differential equations is an interesting question for future studies as the two techniques could be applied to the same ecological system. coredata.dc:description: Abstract The use of quantum information has been proposed as an approach to deal with biological data (Piqueira, J.R.C., Serboncini, F.A., Monteiro, L.H.A., 2006. Biological models: measuring variability with classical and quantum information. J. Theor. Biol. 242 (2), 309–313). Using three-trophic level systems as examples, we show how to model population data by expressing the system states with q-bits. The system time evolution is given by the state transition matrices which relate the states to successive time intervals. It is a complementary way of looking at the problem which is usually modeled with deterministic differential equations. This is possible because the dynamics of interacting populations in three-trophic level systems is a problem with several coupled variables and, consequently, complex dynamical behaviors seem to result. The non deterministic dynamics generated by the state transition matrices is supposed to model the biological system as a whole, with real data expressing even the global effects of small disturbances in the ecological parameters.
